newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia three-month KLIBOR fixed at 9.23 pct.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia three-month KLIBOR fixed at 9.23 pct.

text.p: Malaysia's benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) was fixed at 9.23 percent at 0300 GMT.
It was at 10.3 percent on Wednesday.
The one-month KLIBOR was fixed at 10.13 percent against 11.3 percent on Wednesday.
The money market was closed on Thursday for a Moslem religious holiday.
KLIBOR is fixed by taking an average of rates offered by various banks in the country.
Money market dealers said the market remained short of funds though rates were coming off from earlier highs.
"The market is still short. There's no sign of Bank Negara in the market this morning," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank. "Rates look like they are holding around these levels."
Bank Negara was said to be lending overnight and one-month funds on Wednesday, but only to selected finance and discount houses, dealers said.
The overnight rate was expected to trade between eight and 10 percent, dealers said.
The liquidity squeeze followed heavy buying of the ringgit by the central bank last week to defend the ringgit from a speculative attack.
Although the actual size of the intervention was not known, dealers have estimated that between 2.5 billion and 5.0 billion ringgit was drained from the system.
Dealers said given the continuing pressure on the ringgit, interbank rates were likely to be kept high for the time being.
The ringgit fell to 2.5980/90 to a dollar in Friday morning trade, its weakest level since August 1994.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were slightly higher due to expectations of softening interbank rates.
At 0330 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was up two points to 92.38, or an implied yield of 7.62 percent.
The December contract was unchanged at 92.62, or 7.38 percent.
